channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Read King Charles III’s declaration to the Accession Council.
item.description: In the address, the king mourned the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, and said, “I am deeply aware of this great inheritance and of the duties and heavy responsibilities of sovereignty which have now passed to me.”
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III speaking on Saturday during a meeting of the Accession Council at St. James’s Palace in London.

item.title: In London, Mourning, Remembrance and Tributes. And Some Shrugs.
item.description: Though mourning and grief were visible in Britain’s capital on Friday, some young Britons were more muted in their reaction to an institution that many called increasingly irrelevant.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola, Isabella Kwai and Saskia Solomon
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portrait of Queen Elizabeth is displayed at Victoria Station in London.

item.title: King Charles to Replace Queen Elizabeth on Bank Notes and Coins
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II faced right on British coins. Her son and successor might face the other way.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Since the 17th century, British monarchs have faced the opposite direction of their predecessors on coins.

item.title: Ukraine Attacks Russia in the Kharkiv Region, Swiftly Making Gains
item.description: Sweeping south from positions in the Kharkiv region in Ukraine’s northeast, Ukrainian forces have made their largest gains since routing Russia from Kyiv in April.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Marco Hernandez
item.media:description: Ukrainian fighters in Kharkiv on Friday. President Volodymyr Zelensky said his military had captured large chunks of occupied territory in the north.

item.title: For Ukraine, the Fight Is Often a Game of Bridges
item.description: The southern counteroffensive has been a painstaking battle of river crossings, with pontoon bridges as prime targets for both sides. But so far, it is Ukraine that has advanced.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in a trench on the Kherson front in southern Ukraine this month.

item.title: The American Guided Rockets Helping Ukraine Destroy Russian Forces
item.description: The Guided Multiple Launch Rocket System can hit targets 50 miles away with 200 pounds of explosives.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An M142 High Mobility Artillery Rocket System launching a salvo during exercises last year in Morocco.

item.title: Justice Dept. and Trump Legal Team Clash Over Special Master Candidates
item.description: The two sides had sharply diverging views of who could serve as a special master and what that person would do.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Agents seized more than 11,000 government documents, including about 100 marked as classified, from Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump’s residence in Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: Stephen Miller and Brian Jack Among Those Subpoenaed in Jan. 6 Case
item.description: Stephen Miller, a senior policy adviser, and Brian Jack, who served as White House political director, are among those who received requests for information this week from a federal grand jury.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman, Adam Goldman and Alan Feuer
item.media:description: Stephen Miller, left, with Hogan Gidley, the former White House deputy press secretary.

item.title: Carlos Alcaraz Outlasts Frances Tiafoe to Reach the US Open Final
item.description: The 19-year-old from Spain ended the talented American’s deep run in New York in five sets and will play Casper Ruud of Norway for the men’s singles title.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Carlos Alcaraz is on to the men’s singles final of the U.S. Open.

item.title: US Open Women’s Final Preview: Iga Swiatek vs. Ons Jabeur
item.description: Swiatek will look to affirm her place as the top-ranked player, while Jabeur could become the first African woman to win the U.S. Open.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:description: Ons Jabeur of Tunisia also made it to the final at Wimbledon this year.

item.title: Jann Wenner Wants to Reveal It All
item.description: The Rolling Stone founder talks about LSD, not reading the magazine anymore and how the Stones now look like “Lord of the Rings” characters onstage.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Dana Scruggs for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jann Wenner at his home in Montauk, N.Y., in August.

item.title: Guaranteed Income Programs Spring Up City by City
item.description: Since 2020, four dozen pilot programs have started, with Los Angeles running one of the largest to provide cash assistance.
item.dc:creator: Kurtis Lee
item.media:credit: Adam Perez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alondra Barajas with her daughter, EliAnn, in the Chatsworth neighborhood of Los Angeles.

item.title: Medical Impact of Roe Reversal Goes Beyond Abortion Clinics, Doctors Say
item.description: State abortion bans carry narrow but sometimes vague exceptions, and years of prison time. That’s forcing doctors to think like lawyers, and hospitals to create new protocols.
item.dc:creator: Kate Zernike
item.category: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hospital bed in the emergency department at the University of Wisconsin Hospital in Madison, Wis.

item.title: First Kansas, Next Michigan and Beyond as Abortion Ballot Measures Spread
item.description: Democrats are hoping ballot measures on abortion rights will drive up voter turnout. They’re looking to Michigan as a test run.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: An abortion-rights rally earlier this summer in Lansing, Mich. Democrats in Michigan say a referendum on abortion will supercharge activism among many voters.

item.title: For Florida A&M, Getting on the Field Is Just One of Many Problems
item.description: The university’s football players nearly skipped their opening game in protest of their mismanaged athletic department. Recent history shows far more dysfunction within the university’s sports program.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz
item.media:credit: Malcolm Jackson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bragg Memorial Stadium in Tallahassee, Fla., is the home of Florida A&M football.

item.title: The Disappearing World of Wolfgang Tillmans
item.description: His informal, generous pictures were some of the most moving art of the 1990s. Now, at MoMA, time catches up with the German photographer.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.media:credit: Lila Barth for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gallery with arranged works by Wolfgang Tillmans in “To Look Without Fear” at MoMA, opening Monday. Left, “blue self-portrait shadow” (2020); “Concrete Column” (2021); “Silver 270” (2012), and “Paper Drop Novo” (2022).

item.title: The Royal Grief You Will Not See
item.description: To mourn in public is to feel judged but supported, too.
item.dc:creator: Patti Davis
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Britain’s King Charles III and Queen Camilla at Buckingham Palace.

item.title: Tina Brown: Queen Elizabeth II Loved Her Job
item.description: Without the queen, how will anyone know how to be British anymore?
item.dc:creator: Tina Brown
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
The Palace Papers: Inside the House of Windsor -- the Truth and the Turmoil (Book)

item.title: A Great Podcast, a Worthy Memoir and a Curdled Take on Clarence Thomas
item.description: A fall syllabus.
item.dc:creator: John McWhorter
item.category: Brooklyn College, City University of New York

item.title: What My Family and I Saw When We Were Trapped in China’s Heat Wave
item.description: On a trip through the epicenter, ravaged landscapes, paralyzed cities and populations pushed to extremes.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Bossons
item.media:description: A dry riverbed last month along the Jialing River, a major tributary of the Yangtze River, in Chongqing, China.

item.title: The Treasure America Scavenges From the Poor
item.description: The world’s blood banks are filled with “donations” collected in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Veselka

item.title: Biden Is Telling You That Trump Is a Threat, and the Proof Is Everywhere
item.description: Trump is the chosen candidate of reactionary billionaires and fanatical opponents of racial and gender equality for a reason.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:description: Speaking truth to Trump.

item.title: What John Donne Knew About Death Can Teach Us a Lot About Life
item.description: He thought humans a disaster, the most spectacular disaster there has ever been.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rundell

item.title: What This War Correspondent Wants You to Know About America and Fear
item.description: Luke Mogelson watches the country go berserk in “The Storm Is Here.”
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: The Storm Is Here: An American Crucible (Book)
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A scene at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

item.title: TV’s Prequel-Mania
item.description: This fall, if you feel like you’ve seen that new series somewhere before, you’re probably right.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik
item.category: The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power (TV Program)

item.title: How a Marathon Win 50 Years Ago Kick-Started the ‘Running Boom’
item.description: Frank Shorter couldn’t have imagined the impact his 1972 Olympic marathon victory would have on the sport. “I was just a piece in the puzzle,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:description: Frank Shorter during the men’s marathon at the 1972 Summer Olympics.

item.title: Breakfast With Grandma
item.description: A new New Yorker tucks into the West Village’s offerings with her Abueti, a longtime Manhattanite.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Sichynsky
item.media:description: If you need a more portable breakfast, St. Jardim’s egg sandwich with smoked bacon, tomato jam and greens always satisfies.

item.title: Join Al Gore and John Kerry for a Times Climate Event
item.description: How does climate change exacerbate other global challenges? Join us remotely or in person for our climate event series, with an upcoming gathering in New York in September.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: To Probe Tornado Secrets, These Scientists Stalk Supercells
item.description: We went on the road with scientists crisscrossing the Great Plains, trying to learn how to tell which storms with tornado potential will actually spawn them.
item.dc:creator: Erinn Springer and Mitch Smith

item.title: Downsizing in Retirement: Expenses They Didn’t Expect
item.description: On the way to spending less, people often have to shell out more, at least temporarily — especially when selling a home. Here’s what to consider.
item.dc:creator: Susan B. Garland
item.media:description: Louise Angel Kiss and her husband, Charles, moved to a retirement community in Issaquah, Wash., a few years ago. They weren’t able to sell their old home until they spent thousands of dollars renovating it.

item.title: With Tears and Steel, Kenya’s ‘Hustler’ President Vanquishes His Foes
item.description: William Ruto built a career on beating the odds. In his greatest triumph, he is expected to be inaugurated as Kenya’s fifth president on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President-elect William Ruto addressed supporters last week after the Supreme Court upheld his victory in the Aug. 9 election, at his official residence in Karen, Nairobi.

item.title: Navy Orders High-Level Outside Investigation of SEAL Course
item.description: The punishing selection course for the Navy’s most elite force has come under new scrutiny after a sailor’s death exposed illicit drug use and other problems.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Can Exercise Strengthen Your Immunity?
item.description: Recent research suggests that people who work out have stronger resistance to infectious diseases — including Covid — but experts say the findings need to be tested further.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times

item.title: A Do-Anywhere Full-Body Workout
item.description: It can be done in barely 30 minutes in a hotel room, garage or even an airport lounge. All you need is a jump rope.
item.dc:creator: Gretchen Reynolds

item.title: How to Exercise Mindfully
item.description: Bringing meditation into your movement can enrich your workout and help you feel clearheaded afterward.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Marder
item.media:credit: Sasha Arutyunova for The New York Times

item.title: How to Start Liking Running
item.description: It’s good for your mental and physical health, and doesn’t require any equipment. So why does it seem so hard to get started?
item.dc:creator: Farah Miller

item.title: Can Moving the Body Heal the Mind?
item.description: In her new book, Jennifer Heisz blends personal experience and the latest science about how exercise can improve your mental well-being.
item.dc:creator: Gretchen Reynolds

item.title: ’1776’ Musical Returns to Broadway With a Diverse Twist
item.description: A revival of the classic musical offers a fresh twist on the founding for the post-“Hamilton” era.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Camila Falquez for The New York Times
